results.title: Fresh water: resources at risk
results.creator_credit: National Geographic Society and Sidney Platt
results.brief_description: This documentary takes a look at some of the threats to North America’s water supply and at the actions people are taking to protect the quality and quantity of their freshwater resources. The video begins in the Great Lakes region, where students from Michigan and Ontario test for pollution in rivers that drain into Lake Erie. On the Great Plains, members of the Future Farmers of America are using more efficient irrigation techniques to conserve water stored in the Ogallala aquifer, and they’re sealing abandoned wells that can serve as a direct route for pollution to enter the aquifer. In the Southwest, water from the Colorado River supports agriculture, provides drinking water for city dwellers, and generates electricity - but dams and canals have altered the dynamics of the river. Scientists and students team up to study how the Glen Canyon Dam in Arizona has affected the balance of life in the Grand Canyon. The video wraps up in south Florida, where the increasing demand for water from agriculture and growing urban areas threatens life in the Everglades. In response to public service announcements and other educational efforts, Floridians are learning how they can help conserve their fresh water - tips that apply to people all around North America. Includes a brief teacher’s guide.

results.title: Fresh water from the sea
results.creator_credit: Hearst Metrotone and United States Information Service
results.brief_description: Serious water shortages everywhere have led scientists to seek to transform sea water into fresh water. Two of these conversion plants, one in San Diego, California and the other in Freeport, Texas, are shown in operation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hearst Metrotone and United States Information Service

results.title: Frescoes in Danish churches
results.creator_credit: Dansk Kulturfilm, Teknisk Film, Luciano Emmer and Jorgen Roos
results.brief_description: Uses church frescoes to relate a biblical theme. Depicts the creation and fall of man, the devil and death, the last judgement and hell. No dialogue is spoken in this film.

results.title: French from France: to swim like a fish = Nager comme un poisson
results.creator_credit: Associated Television, Schools Broadcast, Donald Carter and Michael Style
results.brief_description: French language training film. Teaches French conversation, at the beach. Two girls sunbathe, swim, meet their friends and play a ball game. Their lively chatter using a wide vocabulary entertains and helps students with pronunciation in a natural way. Script by Jean Pierre Angremy, starring Claude Carroll as Marianne and Francois Apestoguy as Monique and members of the Comedie De L’Quest, Centre Dramatique National.

results.title: French explorations in the new world
results.brief_description: With the voyage of Verrazano, in 1524, began the story of France in the New World. Tracing the pattern of exploration through Verrazano, Cartier, Champlain, Marquette, Joliet and La Salle, the film shows how soldier-explorers and missionaries planted the earliest of French settlements and laid the foundations for French strongholds in the New World.

results.title: French children: a farm family in Brittany
results.brief_description: Depicts a farm family living in Brittany. Emphasises family life, showing the work of each member and revealing customs and traditions. Includes scenes in a village school, an old castle and a neighbouring farm.

results.title: French Cancan
results.brief_description:
Beautifully photographed, this comedy-drama chronicles the revival of Paris’ most notorious dance as it tells the story of a theater producer who turns a humble washerwoman into a star at the Moulin Rouge. Renoir’s return to film-making in France after 15 years of absence is an exuberant and affectionate homage to the theatre of ‘La Belle Epoque’ (Edith Piaf and Patachou appear briefly as stars of the day.) It also gave him the opportunity to work with Gabin again, having made three films with him in the 1930s. According to Raymond Durgnat, Renoir’s can-can dancers “unleash the insolence not only of proletarian energy, but of the aggressive female, and storm the 19th century bourgeois male patriarchy… A river of feminine energy flows devastatingly, but not destructively, through society”.

Credits: Producer, Louis Wipf ; director, Jean Renoir ; writer, Jean Renoir ; photography, Michel Kelber ; music, Georges Van Parys ; art direction, Max Douy ; costumes, Rosine Delamare ; assistant director, Pierre Kast.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Francoise Arnoul, Maria Felix, Jean-Roger Caussimon, Gianni Esposito.

results.title: French & Saunders: the video
results.brief_description: Dawn French and Jennifer Saunders have formed one of the most successful comedy duos of the 1990’s. This collection of sketches from their successful BBC comedy series contains some of their best material as they disguise themselves in a variety of personas. Their comedy style varies from satire to slapstick and sketches such as “Fat men” and “Bus-stop gynaecology” are guaranteed to generate laughter.
